body.p:
Your editorial article of February 4th entitled
"the mouthpiece of American Israelites" implies two
propositions which are both untrue and mischievous:
1st. That the Jews are merely a race or nation.
2d. That they are not a church.

If these propositions doctrines were true, all the
persecutions they have suffered down to the present German
crusade would be explained if not justified. No
enlightened nation is bound to receive a compact
body of ? men owning a jurisdiction superior to
the properly constituted authorities of their native
land. What evidence or argument can be offered
to prove your views?

When Prior to the formation of the present Union of
American Hebrew Congregations, there was another
Union composed of fewer congregations and their
representatives were called the Board of Delegates of
American Israelites. In that body certain persons
claiming to be Jews eliminated contended that
all matters affecting the welfare of the Jewish
church in the United States should be excluded from
discussion in order to avoid controversy between
the congregations and this anomalous view
finally led to its dissolution and to the incorporation
of its constituents with the union subsequently
formed.

This Union so formed is and ought to be the
only body speaking for American Judaism.
and You however believe that men who refuse
to affiliate with the Jewish church ought to
come forward as representatives of your mythical
Jewish race or nation and act in concert with
each other. Why should they? If the Jewish
church or rather the two Jewish churches, cannot
claim their sympathy, they ought not to per-
petuate a mere prejudice in favor of race.

That For thousands of years Judaism has stood
as a church merely and though its adherents
have been good subjects and citizens of many
states, they have adhered to their religious faith.
It is true that many adherents of this church
believe that in the course of its development
a state representing its doctrines may again
arise to disseminate morality and religion in
ways that we do not now foresee. This sentiment
however is a religious one, part of the body
of the Orthodox Jewish Church, and has no
political significance whatever. I may believe
that the destiny of the United States is to unite
under one free government the whole of the
western continent but this not only need not
weaken my attachment to my country but
on the contrary tends to heighten my love for
it and my faith in the principles actuating
it.

Surely such a faith would be no reason for a refusal to
affiliate with my fellow-Americans in all
public matters, and such a refusal by me would
justly forfeit my claim to be considered a
true American.

So it is with the Jewish church. No man may
turn his back upon her and pretend that he
may speak for her by joining ?
a health and life insurance company like the
Benai Berith and Kindred organizations, or
a Literary and Gymnastic association like the
Young Men's Hebrew Association.

To admit the contrary would be to say that
persons of the Jewish race constitute a separate
organization within the state for purely civil
and social purposes, and this would inevitably
attract hostile criticism and finally political
disfranchisement.

The United States is a free country but
it does not and it ought not to tolerate any
power within its territory that desires to keep up
race distinctions merely. The grand ?
